api.title: API
api.description: If you want to run Prettier programmatically, check this page out.

browser.title: Browser
browser.description: Run Prettier in the browser using its standalone version. This version doesn’t depend on Node.js. It only formats the code and has no support for config files, ignore files, CLI usage, or automatic loading of plugins.

cli.title: CLI
cli.description: Use the prettier command to run Prettier from the command line.

comparison.title: Prettier vs. Linters
comparison.description: How does it compare to ESLint/TSLint/stylelint, etc.?

configuration.title: Configuration File
configuration.description: Prettier uses cosmiconfig for configuration file support. This means you can configure Prettier via (in order of precedence):

editors.title: Editor Integration
editors.description: To get the most out of Prettier, it’s recommended to run it from your editor.

for-enterprise.title: For Enterprise
for-enterprise.description: Available as part of the Tidelift Subscription

ignore.title: Ignoring Code
ignore.description: Use .prettierignore to ignore (i.e. not reformat) certain files and folders completely.

index.title: What is Prettier?
index.description: Prettier is an opinionated code formatter with support for:

integrating-with-linters.title: Integrating with Linters
integrating-with-linters.description: Linters usually contain not only code quality rules, but also stylistic rules. Most stylistic rules are unnecessary when using Prettier, but worse – they might conflict with Prettier! Use Prettier for code formatting concerns, and linters for code-quality concerns, as outlined in Prettier vs. Linters.

option-philosophy.title: Option Philosophy
option-philosophy.description: Prettier has a few options because of history. But we won’t add more of them.

options.title: Options
options.description: Prettier ships with a handful of format options.

plugins.title: Plugins
plugins.description: Plugins are ways of adding new languages or formatting rules to Prettier. Prettier’s own implementations of all languages are expressed using the plugin API. The core prettier package contains JavaScript and other web-focused languages built in. For additional languages you’ll need to install a plugin.

precommit.title: Pre-commit Hook
precommit.description: You can use Prettier with a pre-commit tool. This can re-format your files that are marked as “staged” via git add before you commit.

rationale.title: Rationale
rationale.description: Prettier is an opinionated code formatter. This document explains some of its choices.

technical-details.title: Technical Details
technical-details.description: This printer is a fork of recast’s printer with its algorithm replaced by the one described by Wadler in "A prettier printer". There still may be leftover code from recast that needs to be cleaned up.

vim.title: Vim Setup
vim.description: Vim users can install either vim-prettier, which is Prettier specific, or Neoformat or ALE which are generalized lint/format engines with support for Prettier.

watching-files.title: Watching For Changes
watching-files.description: You can have Prettier watch for changes from the command line by using onchange. For example:

webstorm.title: WebStorm Setup
webstorm.description: JetBrains IDEs (WebStorm, IntelliJ IDEA, PyCharm, etc.)

why-prettier.title: Why Prettier?
why-prettier.description: Building and enforcing a style guide
